funfact: In 2023 Andorra ranked third highest for life expectancy in Europe, at 84.04 years.
More than 90% of Andorra is made up of mountains, forests, rivers, lakes & meadows.
Andorra has more museums per km² than anywhere else in the world.

At the summer solstice fire festivals people flip fireballs into the air - this event is listed as a United Nations Educational, Scientific & Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Intangible Cultural Heritage.
Andorra has never had an army or Ministry of Defence.

quiz.question: What mountain range is Andorra located in?

Which two countries border Andorra?

quizfacts: Andorra is located in the Pyrenees mountain range.
The official language of Andorra is Catalan.
Andorra shares its borders with France & Spain.
Andorra has a Parliamentary Co-Principality form of government.
Andorra is not a member of the European Union.

funfact: Approximately one quarter of the population of Austria lives in Vienna.
Vienna is home to the world's oldest zoo, Tiergarten Schönbrunn, founded in 1752.
More than 62% of Austria is covered by the Austrian Alps, with around 700 peaks higher than 3,000 metres.
Back in 1905 an Austro-Hungarian citizen, Baroness Bertha von Suttner, was the first woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize.
Austria was the first country to issue postcards. Back in 1869 when they were first sold they cost half the price of a regular letter.

quiz.question: Which famous composer was born in Salzburg, Austria?
Austria is home to the headquarters of which international organization?
quiz.correctAnswer: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countires (OPEC)

quiz.question: Austria shares its longest border with which country?

Austria is home to the headquarters of the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC).
Austria shares its longest border with Germany.
The famous palace in Vienna is the Schönbrunn Palace.
Austria is renowned for skiing.

funfact: Despite the name, some historians claim that French fries were actually invented in Belgium in the 1600s.
BMI (Body Mass Index) was invented by Adolphe Quetelet, a Belgian, in 1832.
Belgium went for 652 days without a government between December 2018 & October 2020.
Belgium has more castles per km² than any other country.
Belgium has over 650 varieties of beer, as well as 408 breweries.

quizfacts: Belgium is known for its waffles.
The three official languages of Belgium are French, Dutch, & German.
Brussels, Belgium, is home to the European Union headquarters.
Belgium is particularly famous for Trappist beer.
Belgium is renowned for producing chocolates.

funfact: There is no word meaning "please" in the Danish language.
Denmark has the oldest flag in the world (first acknowledged in 1219).
Danish pastry is called "Viennese bread" in Denmark because it was first introduced to the country by Austrian bakers in the 1840s.
Denmark doesn't have any mountains.
Denmark was the first country to legalise same-sex unions in 1989.

quiz.question: Which Danish author wrote "The Little Mermaid"?

quizfacts: Hans Christian Andersen, a Danish author, wrote The Little Mermaid.
Denmark is known for pioneering wind energy as an environmental initiative.
Tivoli Gardens is a famous amusement park located in Copenhagen.
Denmark is part of the Nordic Countries.
LEGO, the iconic building block toy brand, originated in Denmark.

funfact: Finns consume approximately 12kg of coffee a year on average.
Finland celebrates 'National Sleepy Head Day' on 27th July by playing pranks on late sleepers.
Finnish children usually have 2 birthday parties - one with their friends & one with their families.
74% of Finland is covered by forest.
Finland has more heavy metal bands per capita than any other country in the world.

quiz.question: What is Finland's official language along with Finnish?
Finland is famous for which natural phenomenon?
Which of these is a traditional Finnish sauna feature?
What is Finland’s nickname due to its geography? Land of...

quizfacts: Along with Finnish, Swedish is an official language of Finland.
Finland is famous for the Northern Lights (Aurora Borealis).
Traditional Finnish saunas feature steam & birch twigs.
Finland is nicknamed the "Land of a Thousand Lakes" due to its geography.
Finland is consistently ranked among the top countries in the world for happiness.

funfact: In France since 2016 it has been forbidden to throw away food that is still edible.
France was the first European country to make fitting seatbelts in cars compulsory.
The Tour de France has been held every July since 1903.
Louis XIX was said to have been king for only 22 minutes (while signing his father's abdication document).
France had the first manned hot air balloon flight in 1783.

quiz.question: What is the name of the famous museum in Paris that houses the Mona Lisa?

What iconic French monument was gifted to the United States?

quizfacts: The Louvre is the famous museum in Paris that houses the Mona Lisa.
The Champagne region in France is famous for producing white sparkling wine.
France's national holiday, celebrated on July 14th, is called Bastille Day.
Lyon is known as the culinary capital of France.
The Statue of Liberty was an iconic monument gifted by France to the United States.

funfact: Beer is considered to be a food in Bavaria.
German shares 60% of its vocabulary with English.
Germany has more football fan clubs than any other country.
Berlin has Europe's biggest train station.
Fanta was created in Germany during World War II because they were unable to import Coca-Cola syrup.

quiz.question: Which German city is known as the birthplace of Beethoven?
What is the traditional German dish made of fermented cabbage?
What German highway is famous for having stretches without a speed limit?
Germany is the largest producer of what type of energy in Europe?
Which major German festival is celebrated in Munich?

quizfacts: Bonn is the German city known as the birthplace of Beethoven.
Sauerkraut, made of fermented cabbage, is a traditional German dish.
The Autobahn is the famous German highway with stretches that have no speed limit.
Germany is the largest producer of wind energy in Europe.
Oktoberfest is a major German festival celebrated in Munich.

funfact: The Ancient Greeks invented theatre, but only males could be actors.
Greece is one of the sunniest countries in the world, with about 3,000 hours of sunshine a year.
80% of Greece is made up of mountains.
The Greek island Santorini has red, black & white beaches.
Greece's national animal is a dolphin, representing the country's maritime heritage.

quiz.question: What is the name of the hill in Athens that houses the Parthenon?

quizfacts: The Acropolis in Athens houses the Parthenon.
Santorini is the Greek island famous for its white-washed buildings & blue domes.
Greece is considered the birthplace of democracy.
The Aegean Sea borders Greece to the east.
Gyro is a traditional Greek dish made of meat roasted on a vertical spit.

funfact: Iceland has the oldest parliament in Europe - Althingi, established in 930 AD.
There is only one native land mammal in Iceland: the Arctic fox. There are no polar bears!
There are no mosquitoes in Iceland thanks to its cold climate & lack of suitable breeding habitats.
Once an Icelandic horse leaves the country, it is not allowed to return, in order to avoid the introduction of diseases.
A traditional Icelandic bread baking technique involves burying the dough near hot springs to bake slowly using natural heat.

quiz.question: What is Iceland's most famous geothermal spa?
What percentage of Iceland is covered by glaciers?
Which Icelandic volcano caused major air travel disruptions in 2010?
What is the national sport of Iceland?
What type of energy is Iceland primarily powered by?

quizfacts: Iceland's most famous geothermal spa is the Blue Lagoon.
Iceland is known for not having snakes in the wild.
The Icelandic volcano Eyjafjallajökull caused major air travel disruptions in 2010.
Handball is the national sport of Iceland.
Iceland is primarily powered by geothermal energy.

funfact: Halloween originated in Ireland, from the ancient Celtic festival of Samhain that marked the beginning of winter.
There are no snakes in Ireland - it was too cold for them until the end of the last ice age, after which Ireland was separated from other landmasses.
Ireland has the oldest intact operational lighthouse in the world, Hook Lighthouse, built in 1172.
There is a festival called the Puck Fair in Ireland where a wild goat is caught & made king for 3 days.
At 2,500km in length, Ireland's Wild Atlantic Way coastal route is the longest in the world.

quiz.question: Which Irish holiday is celebrated worldwide on March 17th?
Which Irish author wrote "Ulysses"
What is the traditional Irish dance style known as?
What is the name of the famous stone at Blarney Castle?
Ireland is known as the "Emerald Isle" due to what?

quizfacts: St. Patrick's Day is celebrated worldwide on March 17th.
James Joyce, an Irish author, wrote Ulysses.
The traditional Irish dance style is called Ceili dancing.
The famous stone at Blarney Castle is the Blarney Stone.
Ireland is known as the "Emerald Isle" due to its lush green landscapes.

funfact: Cats have rights in Italy - anyone convicted of killing a cat could face a €10,000 fine & up to 3 years in prison.
The Italian Police Force uses Lamborghinis.
The average Italian consumes 25kg of pasta per year.
The University of Bologna, founded in 1088, is the oldest university still in operation today.
The first spectacles were made in Italy in the late 1200s.

quiz.question: What is the name of the famous Roman amphitheatre in Italy?

quizfacts: The famous Roman amphitheatre in Italy is the Colosseum.
Italy is the birthplace of Michelangelo, the famous Renaissance artist who painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling.
Venice is the Italian city famous for its canals.
Italy's highest mountain is Mont Blanc.
Risotto is the Italian dish made of rice, often cooked with saffron.

funfact: Liechtenstein is one of the smallest countries in the world, covering just 160km², but it has one of the highest GDPs per capita globally.
Liechtenstein abolished its army in 1868 due to cost concerns. Today, the country relies on Switzerland for defense if needed.
Liechtenstein is one of only two double-landlocked countries in the world: it is landlocked & surrounded entirely by other landlocked countries (Switzerland & Austria).
Once a year, Liechtenstein allows companies or individuals to "rent" the entire country for private events, complete with a symbolic key to the nation.
Liechtenstein's prince has significant political influence, including the ability to veto laws & dissolve parliament.

quiz.question: Liechtenstein is one of the smallest countries in the worlWhich two countries border it?
What type of government does Liechtenstein have?
Liechtenstein is known for its strong economy based on which sector?

quizfacts: Liechtenstein borders Switzerland & Austria.
Liechtenstein has a Constitutional Monarchy.
Liechtenstein is known for its strong economy based on financial services.
Liechtenstein is part of the European Economic Area (EEA), despite not being in the European Union.
The official language of Liechtenstein is German.

funfact: Luxembourg has won the Eurovision Song Contest 5 times as of 2024.
The national dish of Luxembourg is smoked pork & broad beans.
The Luxembourg underground tunnel system from the 17th & 18th centuries contains an area of over 17km.
Public transport is free in Luxembourg, including trains, trams & buses.
Luxembourg City has been listed twice as the European Capital of Culture.

quiz.question: Luxembourg is one of the founding members of which organization?

Dutch is not one of Luxembourg's three official languages.
Luxembourg's nickname due to its size is the "Gibraltar of the North."
Steel production is historically significant in Luxembourg's economy.
Luxembourg is known for its unique financial feature of low tax rates.

funfact: There are no natural lakes or rivers in Malta so they have to filter their drinking water straight from the sea.
Valletta, the capital of Malta, was the first ever planned city in Europe, back in 1565, & was built in only 15 years.
The national dish of Malta is "Stuffat tal-Fenek", a type of rabbit stew.
Malta is not one island but an archipelago.
Malta is one of only 4 European countries where people drive on the left hand side of the road.

quiz.question: What unique tradition is Malta known for during its summer months?

quizfacts: Malta is known for its unique tradition of firework festivals in every village during the summer months.

Malta's largest island is Malta.
The traditional Maltese boat is called a Luzzu.
Malta is known for its role in World War II.

funfact: Monaco has around one police officer for every 70 residents.

The most popular sports in Monaco are football, sailing, yachting & tennis.
One in three people in Monaco is a millionaire.
Monaco does not allow its own citizens to enter its casinos.

funfact: The world's first airport library was opened in Schiphol Airport, Amsterdam in 2010.
In 2001 the Netherlands became the first country to legalise same-sex marriage.
One third of the Netherlands is below sea level.
The Netherlands is the world's biggest cut flower exporter (in 2022 they exported €81.9 million-worth of tulips).
The Dutch are the biggest consumers of liquorice in the world, eating nearly 2kg per person per year.

quiz.question: What flower is most associated with the Netherlands?

What is the traditional Dutch wooden shoe called?

quizfacts: The flower most associated with the Netherlands is the tulip.
Amsterdam is known for its extensive canal system & the Anne Frank House.
The traditional Dutch wooden shoe is called a clog.
Brie is not a Dutch cheese; the Netherlands is famous for Gouda, Edam, & Leyden.
The official seat of government in the Netherlands is The Hague.

funfact: When a new book is published in Norway, at least 1,000 copies are bought by the government & put in libraries across the country.
Salmon sushi is not native to Japan - it was introduced to them by Norway.
Norway is home to Europe's biggest herd of wild reindeer.
The longest road tunnel in the world is in Norway: the Lærdalstunnelen which is 24.5km long.
The cheese slicer was invented in 1925 by a Norwegian cabinet maker called Thor Bjørklund, who took inspiration from the planer he used for work.

quiz.question: Norway is known as the "Land of the Midnight Sun" because the sun doesn't set during which season?

quizfacts: Norway is known as the "Land of the Midnight Sun" because the sun doesn't set during the summer season.
Norway is famous for its fjords, a distinctive coastline feature.
Skiing is a winter sport deeply rooted in Norwegian culture.
Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian explorer, was the first to reach the South Pole.
Norway's official language is Norwegian.

funfact: The Bertrand Bookstore in Lisbon, established in 1732, holds the Guinness World Record as the oldest operating bookstore in the world.
Portugal is home to the Vasco da Gama Bridge, which spans over 17km & crosses the Tagus River in Lisbon.
Fado, a genre of Portuguese music known for its melancholic tunes & soulful lyrics, is a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage.
Portugal produces more than 50% of the world's cork. Its vast cork oak forests supply material for wine stoppers & other products.
In the 1494 Treaty of Tordesillas Portugal & Spain divided the world between them. Portugal was assigned Brazil & parts of Africa & Asia.

quiz.question: What is the name of Portugal's famous fortified wine?

quizfacts: Portugal's famous fortified wine is Port.
Portugal is known for its decorative ceramic tiles called Azulejos.
Vasco da Gama was the Portuguese explorer who was the first to reach India by sea.
The famous Portuguese custard tart is Pastéis de Nata.
Portugal shares its only land border with Spain.

funfact: San Marino is the only country in the world that has more registered cars than residents officially living there.
San Marino is the 5th smallest country in the world at just 61km².
San Marino is considered the oldest Republic in the world, having been founded in 301 AD.
San Marino doesn't have a commercial airport.
The country's name is derived from Saint Marinus, a Christian who lived there while escaping religious persecution by the Roman Empire.

quiz.question: Which of these is a typical Christmas soup in San Marino?

quizfacts: A typical Christmas soup in San Marino is Bean & Bacon.

The Adriatic coast is near San Marino.
San Marino is geographically divided into nine Castelli.
Before the Euro, San Marino used the Sammarinese lira as its currency.

funfact: Spanish is the second most widely spoken language in the world.
"Tapas" means "to cover". Long ago people started covering their drinks with slices of bread & meat to protect them from dust.
Spain claims to have the oldest restaurant in the world: Restaurante Botín in Madrid, which has been open since 1725.
The Spanish national anthem, Marcha Real, has no words - at sporting events the audience normally just hum along.
Sagrada Familia has been under construction since 1882 & as of 2025 hasn't been finished - but it does have UNESCO World Heritage status.

quiz.question: Which Spanish festival involves participants throwing tomatoes at each other?

quizfacts: The Spanish festival where participants throw tomatoes at each other is La Tomatina.
Flamenco is the traditional Spanish dance with fast-paced guitar music.
Pablo Picasso, the famous Spanish painter, created "Guernica."
Spain's national dish, made of rice, saffron, & seafood or meat, is Paella.
The famous pilgrimage route in Spain is the Camino de Santiago.

funfact: Sweden has approximately 267,000 islands, more than any other country in the world, though only about 1,000 of them are inhabited.
Sweden grants everyone the "Right to Roam": people can hike, camp, & forage freely on public & private land, as long as they respect nature & property.
The Nobel Prize originated in Sweden. Alfred Nobel, a Swedish inventor, established the awards in his will.
Sweden is home to the world's first ice hotel, located in Jukkasjärvi, which is rebuilt every winter using ice from the Torne River.
October 4th is celebrated as Kanelbullens Dag (Cinnamon Bun Day) in Sweden, dedicated to the beloved Swedish pastry.

quiz.question: Sweden is known for its flat-packed furniture company. What is its name?

Sweden is part of which group of Nordic countries?
What is Sweden's largest & deepest lake?

quizfacts: Sweden is known for IKEA, a flat-packed furniture company.
The traditional Swedish holiday celebrated in June is Midsummer.
Sweden is part of the Scandinavian group of Nordic countries.
Sweden's largest & deepest lake is Vänern.
ABBA, the famous Swedish pop group, became internationally renowned in the 1970s.

funfact: The iconic Swiss Army Knife was first produced in 1891 & became a symbol of Swiss craftsmanship & practicality.
Switzerland doesn't have an official capital. Bern serves as the de facto capital because it hosts the federal government.
Switzerland has about 1.5 million cows, which are treated with great care & even "vacation" in alpine pastures during summer.
Switzerland has remained neutral in international conflicts since the early 19th century, even avoiding involvement in both World Wars.
Switzerland is home to some of the cleanest cities globally, thanks to its strict recycling laws & commitment to sustainability.

quiz.question: Switzerland is home to which international organization?

Switzerland has four official languages. Which of these is NOT one of them?

quizfacts: Switzerland is home to the Red Cross, an international organization.
The most famous type of Swiss cheese is Gruyère.
Dutch is not one of Switzerland's four official languages.
Switzerland is famous for producing watches & chocolate.
The Alps mountain range dominates Switzerland's landscape.

funfact: Istanbul is famously home to thousands of stray cats that are cared for by the community & have become a unique part of the city's culture.
While tulips are often associated with the Netherlands, they actually originated in Turkey & were brought to Europe during the Ottoman Empire.
The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, built in 1461, is considered the world's first shopping mall. It remains a bustling market with over 4,000 shops.
Turkey has unique milk-based desserts like "kazandibi" (burnt pudding) & "sütlaç" (rice pudding), which are beloved across the country.
Turkey has numerous underground cities. These cities were used for protection during invasions & could house thousands of people.

quiz.question: What does a kiss on the hand mean in Turkey?

Which of these is the most important building in Turkey?

quizfacts: A kiss on the hand in Turkey is a sign of respect & love.
A famous dish from Turkey is doner kebab.
The national animal of Turkey is the grey wolf.
The most important building in Turkey is the Hagia Sofia Grand Mosque.
The most popular drink in Turkey is tea.

funfact: Alfred the Great, considered by some to be the first King of England, made it a law for everyone to be in bed by 8pm & introduced a curfew bell.
The Penny Black, the world's first public-use adhesive postage stamp, first went on sale in the UK in 1840.
In the Isle of Man, there's no national speed limit - some roads may be driven at any speed which is safe & appropriate.
Two mice fighting over a slice of cheese is London's smallest statue.
In the UK all horses, donkeys & ponies must have a horse passport.

quiz.question: What is the name of the UK's famous clock tower?
Which river runs through London?
The United Kingdom is made up of how many countries?
What is the name of the famous prehistoric monument in England?
What is the national dish of the UK often associated with Fridays?

quizfacts: The UK's famous clock tower is named Elizabeth Tower.
The river that runs through London is the Thames.
The United Kingdom is made up of four countries.
The famous prehistoric monument in England is Stonehenge.
The national dish of the UK often associated with Fridays is fish & chips.
